overview_content.description: Fundamental Rights are the basic human rights enshrined in the Constitution of India which are guaranteed to all citizens. They are enforceable by the courts, subject to specific restrictions. These rights are crucial for the all-round development of individuals and to preserve human dignity.
overview_content.location_in_constitution: Part III of the Constitution from Articles 12 to 35.
importance: Serve as limitations on government power
Ensure the democratic nature of our polity
Part of the "basic structure" of the Constitution, meaning they cannot be removed even by constitutional amendment

content.definition: Fundamental Rights are basic rights that are guaranteed to all citizens by the Constitution.
key_points: Essential for the all-round development of individuals
Protected and enforceable by courts
Available against the state (with some exceptions that can be enforced against individuals too)
Not absolute (have reasonable restrictions)

need_for_fundamental_rights.protection_against_state_tyranny: They limit government power and prevent abuse of authority
need_for_fundamental_rights.promotion_of_dignity: They ensure respect for human dignity and worth
need_for_fundamental_rights.establishment_of_democracy: They are essential for a functioning democracy
need_for_fundamental_rights.protection_of_minorities: They safeguard the rights of minority groups
need_for_fundamental_rights.social_transformation: They help in removing social evils like untouchability

article_14.title: Equality Before Law
article_14.description: The State shall not deny to any person equality before the law or the equal protection of the laws within the territory of India.
key_points: Equality before law means that no person is above the law
Equal protection of laws means that equals should be treated equally
Allows for reasonable classification but prohibits class legislation

article_15.title: Prohibition of Discrimination
article_15.description: The State shall not discriminate against any citizen on grounds only of religion, race, caste, sex, place of birth or any of them.
key_points: Prohibits discrimination in access to public places
Allows for special provisions for women and children
Permits affirmative action for socially and educationally backward classes

article_16.title: Equality of Opportunity in Public Employment
article_16.description: There shall be equality of opportunity for all citizens in matters relating to employment or appointment to any office under the State.
key_points: Prohibits discrimination in public employment
Allows for reservation in favor of backward classes
Permits residence requirements for certain employments

article_17.title: Abolition of Untouchability
article_17.description: Untouchability is abolished and its practice in any form is forbidden.
key_points: Complete abolition of untouchability
Practice of untouchability is a punishable offense
Enforced through the Protection of Civil Rights Act, 1955

article_18.title: Abolition of Titles
article_18.description: No title, not being a military or academic distinction, shall be conferred by the State.
key_points: Prohibits state from conferring titles
Prohibits citizens from accepting titles from foreign states
Exceptions for military and academic distinctions

article_19.title: Protection of Six Freedoms
article_19.description: All citizens shall have the right to freedom of speech and expression, assembly, association, movement, residence, and profession.
freedoms: Freedom to assemble peaceably and without arms
Freedom to form associations or unions
Freedom to move freely throughout the territory of India
Freedom to reside and settle in any part of India
Freedom to practice any profession or to carry on any occupation, trade or business

article_20.title: Protection in Respect of Conviction for Offences
article_20.description: No person shall be convicted of any offense except for violation of a law in force at the time of the commission of the act.

article_21.title: Protection of Life and Personal Liberty
article_21.description: No person shall be deprived of his life or personal liberty except according to procedure established by law.
key_points: Right to life includes right to live with human dignity
Right to personal liberty includes various freedoms
Procedure established by law must be fair, just and reasonable

article_22.title: Protection Against Arrest and Detention
article_22.description: No person who is arrested shall be detained in custody without being informed of the grounds for such arrest.
protections: Right to be informed of grounds of arrest
Right to consult and be defended by a legal practitioner
Right to be produced before a magistrate within 24 hours

article_23.title: Prohibition of Traffic in Human Beings and Forced Labour
article_23.description: Traffic in human beings and begar and other similar forms of forced labour are prohibited.
key_points: Prohibits human trafficking
Prohibits forced labour
Prohibits begar (unpaid forced labour)
Exception for compulsory service for public purposes

article_24.title: Prohibition of Employment of Children in Factories
article_24.description: No child below the age of fourteen years shall be employed to work in any factory or mine or engaged in any other hazardous employment.
key_points: Prohibits child labour in hazardous occupations
Applies to factories, mines and other hazardous employments
Implemented through the Child Labour (Prohibition and Regulation) Act, 1986

article_25.title: Freedom of Conscience and Free Profession
article_25.description: All persons are equally entitled to freedom of conscience and the right freely to profess, practice and propagate religion.
key_points: Freedom of conscience
Right to profess religion
Right to practice religion
Right to propagate religion
Subject to public order, morality and health

article_26.title: Freedom to Manage Religious Affairs
article_26.description: Every religious denomination has the right to establish and maintain institutions for religious and charitable purposes.
rights: Right to establish and maintain institutions
Right to manage its own affairs in matters of religion
Right to own and acquire property

article_27.title: Freedom from Payment of Taxes for Promotion of Religion
article_27.description: No person shall be compelled to pay any taxes for the promotion or maintenance of any particular religion.
key_points: Prohibits compulsory religious taxes
Applies to all religions equally
Does not prevent state from spending on religious institutions

article_28.title: Freedom from Religious Instruction in Educational Institutions
article_28.description: No religious instruction shall be provided in any educational institution wholly maintained out of State funds.
key_points: Prohibits religious instruction in state-funded institutions
Allows religious instruction in private institutions
Protects students from compulsory religious instruction

article_29.title: Protection of Interests of Minorities
article_29.description: Any section of citizens having a distinct language, script or culture shall have the right to conserve the same.
rights: Right to conserve language, script and culture
Right to admission in educational institutions
Protection against discrimination in educational institutions

article_30.title: Right of Minorities to Establish Educational Institutions
article_30.description: All minorities, whether based on religion or language, shall have the right to establish and administer educational institutions of their choice.
rights: Protection against discrimination in state aid

content.description: The right to move the Supreme Court for enforcement of Fundamental Rights is itself a Fundamental Right.

writs.habeas_corpus: To produce the body of a person who has been detained
writs.mandamus: To command a public official to perform their duty
writs.prohibition: To prohibit a lower court from exceeding its jurisdiction
writs.certiorari: To quash the order of a lower court
writs.quo_warranto: To question the authority of a person holding a public office

importance: Heart and soul of the Constitution
Makes Fundamental Rights meaningful and enforceable
Empowers citizens to approach the Supreme Court directly
